Timeline: Astronomy

Uzair Tahamid Siam

  • 2019: First exposure to rigorous astronomy

    Fall of 2019 was my first time taking an astronomy course, The Solar System and Its Origin. It was quite an intense course for a freshman to be quite fair. As the name suggests, it delved into the structures and dynamics of the celestial bodies in the Solar System. Covering topics ranging from celestial coordinate systems, compositions of rocks on the moon, asteroids, and atmospheres of planets to dynamics of the large-scale bodies themselves as well their moons. The class also involved an observation project at the CEK MEES Observatory, something I would say anyone interested in astronomy would love to experience

  • 2020: Introduction to Astrophysics

    Spring 2020 was my first introduction to modern astrophysics. The course I was taking, Honors Elementary Astrophysics is to date one of the most difficult classes I have taken. Often to referred to as a survey course, it covers an intermediate level of depth in essentially every subfield of astrophysics in modern times. To name a few, it covers the mantiude scale used for brightness, magnitude correction methods to account for extinction and reddening of light, stellar formation and evolution, black holes, dark matter and energy, as well as cosmology and the fate of the universe. This is one of my favorite courses ever and something I would suggest everyone to take

  • 2020: First Research Experience

  • 2021: Diving Into Observational Astronomy

  • 2021: New Found Love for Exoplanets

  • 2021: Learning About Our Galaxy

  • 2022: More about Astrophysics

  • 2022: More Expoplanets Yay!
